articles.headline: Online Deals for Holiday Shopping: Buyer Beware
articles.snippet: Much of what look like holiday-season steals are in fact no such thing. A watchdog group found under 1 percent of the “deals” it looked at actually were.
articles.abstract: Much of what look like holiday-season steals are in fact no such thing. A watchdog group found under 1 percent of the “deals” it looked at actually were.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Black Friday, Kohl’s offered what looked like a terrific deal on the Jawbone UP24, a stylish fitness-tracking band the retailer ordinarily sells for $130.

articles.headline: The Mergers and Acquisitions Cycle: Buy. Divide. Conquer.
articles.snippet: The current deal-making boom has been filled with headline-grabbing mergers. At the same time, corporate America is spinning off assets by the truckload. Who is creating more value?
articles.abstract: The current deal-making boom has been filled with headline-grabbing mergers. At the same time, corporate America is spinning off assets by the truckload. Who is creating more value?
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2001, Hewlett-Packard announced a momentous $25 billion merger with Compaq.

articles.headline: For Afghans, Name and Birthdate Census Questions Are Not So Simple
articles.snippet: Culture is a census obstacle: Many Afghans lack surnames, most do not know their birthday and women will not speak if their husbands are out.
articles.abstract: Culture is a census obstacle: Many Afghans lack surnames, most do not know their birthday and women will not speak if their husbands are out.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Khaliddudin, who like many Afghans goes by a single name, has already picked out a second name to go alongside the first. He has decided on “Mayroj,” which, he proudly explained, means the “highest.”

articles.headline: Many Feel the American Dream Is Out of Reach, Poll Shows
articles.snippet: Only 64 percent of respondents in an opinion poll on economic and financial issues said they still believed in the American dream, the lowest result in roughly two decades.
articles.abstract: Only 64 percent of respondents in an opinion poll on economic and financial issues said they still believed in the American dream, the lowest result in roughly two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite an improving economy and jobs picture, the public is more pessimistic than it was after the 2008 financial crisis that it is possible to work hard and become rich, according to a New York Times poll.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Lending Club Set to Debut, and Industry Is Watching
articles.snippet: The eight-year-old company priced its stock at $15 a share, more than the most recent expected range of $12 to $14. At that level, the offering values the company at $5.4 billion.
articles.abstract: The eight-year-old company priced its stock at $15 a share, more than the most recent expected range of $12 to $14. At that level, the offering values the company at $5.4 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lending Club makes its debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, it will carry the hopes of an entire industry.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Sony Hack Reveals Email Crossfire Over Angelina Jolie and Steve Jobs Movie
articles.snippet: Among the information spilled forth in a breach of Sony’s studio, perhaps nothing has riveted Hollywood more than a humiliating email exchange about Angelina Jolie.
articles.abstract: Among the information spilled forth in a breach of Sony’s studio, perhaps nothing has riveted Hollywood more than a humiliating email exchange about Angelina Jolie.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Salaries of its top executives. Unpublished scripts. Sensitive contracts. Aliases that stars use to check into hotels.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Slide in Fuel Costs Lifts Profits for Airlines, but Fares Won’t Fall
articles.snippet: Although oil prices are down more than 40 percent since June, airline executives say other expenses rose and they are reinvesting in their companies.
articles.abstract: Although oil prices are down more than 40 percent since June, airline executives say other expenses rose and they are reinvesting in their companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A recovering economy and rapidly falling oil prices have provided some breathing room for airlines in recent months, bolstering profits and allowing carriers to buy new planes or upgrade their higher-end service.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Torture Report Puts Presidential Hopefuls in Quiet Mode
articles.snippet: Most of the presumptive presidential candidates have not plunged into Washington’s debate over the Senate Intelligence Committee’s withering report on the C.I.A.’s brutal interrogation tactics.
articles.abstract: Most of the presumptive presidential candidates have not plunged into Washington’s debate over the Senate Intelligence Committee’s withering report on the C.I.A.’s brutal interrogation tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2002, not long after President George W. Bush named him the top federal prosecutor in New Jersey, Chris Christie emphatically and unexpectedly denounced torture as a means of gathering evidence.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: C.I.A. First Planned Jails Abiding by U.S. Standards
articles.snippet: The agency envisioned a system in which detainees would be offered the same rights and protections as inmates held in federal or American military prisons.
articles.abstract: The agency envisioned a system in which detainees would be offered the same rights and protections as inmates held in federal or American military prisons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just six days after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, President Bush signed a secret order that gave the Central Intelligence Agency the power to capture and imprison terrorists with Al Qaeda. But the order said nothing about where they should be held or how the agency should go about the business of questioning them.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and James Risen

articles.headline: Hong Kong Protesters Lose a Last Bastion, but Vow to Go On
articles.snippet: Even in their defeat, the protesters, mostly college students, left with a new sense of political identity and a willingness to challenge the power holders in Beijing.
articles.abstract: Even in their defeat, the protesters, mostly college students, left with a new sense of political identity and a willingness to challenge the power holders in Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Constance So, a slightly built university student, wept as she looked for a way past the tightening ring of police officers closing in on the last of the sizable protest camps in Hong Kong.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
